Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Bio-Inspired Predictive Engineering Analysis Tool
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project is to obtain the benefits available from modernizing legacy processes in the made-to-order design manufacturing industry. Traditionally the mathematical processes used to analyze potential designs are very linear in nature, and do not offer the manufacturer a complete picture of the overall impacts of the non-linear parts of their designs. With the predictive engineering analysis tool developed here, a manufacturing facility can preview the results available from using a particular engineering design prior to the actual manufacturing and testing of the physical parts. Design parameters and environmental conditions can also be inserted into the tool which are then used to better predict the behavior of the part after it is produced. This innovative virtual tool has the potential to be added to the set of existing design and testing tools already being used and let manufacturers predict the success or failure of a part. The impact of this tool would be decreased time to market, eliminating the guesswork now used in certain aspects of a design and saving valuable physical resources.

This I-Corps project defines an innovative scalable software tool that is capable of virtually predicting the success or failure of an engineering design prior to production. The technique is based on the mathematical modeling of the coordinated behaviors of biological system. This allows the tool to quickly search and intelligently predict the best solution sets to a multi-objective problem in a given design space. This project employs these innovative bio-inspired techniques to develop algorithms which are applied to engineering designs to produce an ideal set of solutions based on user defined objectives. Bio-inspired algorithms have been shown to improve upon current standard rigid mathematical techniques. This project provides the flexibility to implement an approach that is able to search the entire problem space at once therefore giving better visibility to all of the possible solutions. Since no particular parameter in isolation impacts the outcome of the algorithm, the user is presented with the opportunity to shift the input parameters and rerun the optimization. Further this I-Corps project attempts to explore and define the input parameters for a variety of industries, and assist the end user in coming up with better designs for their products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Objective: The main objective of the NSF I Corps grant was to explore the market opportunities for a software tool nicknamed BIPEAT (Bio-Inspired Predictive Engineering Analysis Tool). This tool is a reference point multi-objective optimizer based on a very novel paradigm inspired by nature. The tool is based on the group hunting behaviors of Harris hawks. Reference Point is the region where the optimal point is being explored. It symbolizes the hawks perched on the treetop looking for a prey in the immediate surroundings. If a prey is located then the hawk on the treetop coordinates with hawks on the ground to capture the prey. If not then hawk moves to another treetop to look for a potential prey.

For the NSF I Corps project, BIPEAT predicts the quality of hardness of a metal part for specific inputs of furnace time, furnace temperature, quantity of ammonia, carbon and batch size. The tool virtually processes the metal part and predicts hardness. The tool envisages reducing the wastage of material, person-hours, furnace time and thus reducing the overall cost. At present, the recipes are developed using tribal knowledge and are perfected with trials thus wasting material, person-hour, furnace time etc. 

We interviewed furnace manufacturers, foundries; heat treat facilities both regulated and non-regulated, platers and coaters, assemblers, job shop scheduling software companies, aerospace manufacturers and plastic heat-treat facilities.  During the course of our interviews, to find the market potential of BIPEAT we found, that recipe market is rather limited as government and industry strictly regulate the recipes for heat-treating parts for aerospace, military and automotive industry..

However, we discovered these heat treat facilities could optimize the scheduling of the processes of heat treat to increase the production and meet the on time delivery requirements.

We also learnt that heat treat is not a stand-alone process. The success or failure of the parts also depends on the quality of those parts as they moved through the entire ecosystem of forging, machining, heat-treating and coating. It was discovered that we should expand our thinking to optimizing not only recipes for heat-treating but also recipes for forging and coating or plating the parts. 

Another pivot point came when we found that there was a need to optimize not only small simple parts for production but also to optimize the performance of complex parts made by assembling simple individual parts, for example, an airplane landing gear assembly. We learned during these interviews that there was no standard procedure to optimize the stresses and loads on the combination of parts in a non-linear way. At present, only a more complex and computationally intensive linear analysis exists on the market. We think that BIPEAT can be tailored to develop a load stress model for complex parts.

However, we also realized that heat treat process is applicable to materials other than metals such as medical and food grade plastic parts. Similar to the heat-treating industry, these industries have very specific recipe requirements for their products that are controlled by strict industry regulations. These products also go through a heat-treating process that sterilizes the materials prior to utilization with machinery and process steps that are similar to the ones used to harden metal parts. We found during these interviews that no software package exists that could optimize these process steps prior to production to improve throughput.

Therefore, we realized there is need to do more research to verify and test our model for the application domains and for that we need to discover industry partners who are willing to work with us and give us preliminary data for this purpose of virtually predicting the outcomes of these processes before actually implementing them.

 

 


Last Modified: 12/07/2018
Modified by: Devinder Kaur
